author: Special Correspondent
text:
Specialists examined 306 persons at a follow-up camp for cancer patients here on Sunday held under the auspices of the Health Department and Non-Communicable Disease Unit of the Tamil Nadu Health Systems Project.

Their problem was detected during camps held between 2011 and 2016. Of them, 55 were found suffering from with cervix cancer, 144 were referred for colposcopy and 107 were found with early symptoms of the disease, said V. C. Subash Gandhi, Research Scholar of the Tamil Nadu Health System Project, who was formerly the camp coordinator under the Non-Communicable Disease wing of the Tamil Nadu Health System Project.

D. Parimala Devi, Dean of the Pudukottai Government Hospital, said these patients would be referred to advanced treatment including Hysterectomy, radiotherapy, chemotherapy.

The camp aimed at ensuring case-specific follow-up treatment under the Chief Minister’s Health Insurance Scheme, she added.

The patients had come from Gandarvakottai, Tirumayam, Mazhaiyur, Manamelkudi and Kottaipattinam, according to Dr. Parimala Devi.

The special camp formed part of the free general health camp in which as many as 2,856 persons were screened for various ailments. An exhibition was organised.

S. Ganesh, Collector, declared open the exhibition. As many as 13 stalls were set up at the exhibition on various topics including ‘Healthy kolu’, ‘healthy house’ and ‘plastic-free environment’.

Exhibits and models on the theme ‘prevention of dengue’ and ‘control of non-communicable diseases’ and ‘cardiac care’ were displayed on the occasion.
title: Follow-up camp for cancer patients
